And he immediately takes it.  Perhaps it was the Bishop aiming at a7; whatever the reason, Kb8 will cost Black nothing less than a Rook.
Black can alleviate the mating threat but cannot simultaneously protect his Rook.
He misses my mating threat, saves his Rook and threatens his own mate.
Maybe he was hoping I did not know what I had and would play Kg1.  Better to have given up the Rook with say b7 or c5 although an ultimate loss would still have been likely.
